Ye shepherds attend to my lay,</br>Which gratefully I do rehearse,</br>To the memory of tuneful Gay,</br>The Shakespeare of Pastoral Verse.
His manners were gentle and mild,</br>As his converse was rural and sweet;</br>He was justly "Simplicity's child,"</br>As immortal Pope doth repeat.
His truely Theocritan strains,</br>Wherever he warbled his reed,</br>Bespeak him, of all the gay swains,</br>The shepherd of worthiest meed.
The sweet eclogues, which Cunningham sung,</br>Our sorrow shou'd never abate;</br>Nor the harmony of Shenstone's tongue,</br>His loss to us e'er compensate.
For can we so quickly forget,</br>Or e'er it so happ'ly repair,</br>As his Grubbinol and Bumpkinet,</br>Did that of their Blouzelind fair.
"What of Shenstone (mild Cunningham said)</br>I with justness do humbly deny,</br>Since with Gay the true pastoral fled,</br>And with him too, I fear, it did die."
The Bucolic rivals dispute,</br>About whether deserved the bays,</br>Was instantly silent and mute,</br>When were seen Damon's worthier lays.
So to him the fair laurel was borne</br>By Genius, as justly his own;</br>Which, while living, his brow did adorn,</br>And since dead, on his tomb's ever grown.
Tho' on each annual eve of his death,</br>For a space it is withered seen,</br>Till — from a breeze of his Fame's balmy breath,</br>It re-bloometh more lovely and green.
Long, ye nymphs and ye lambkins, bewail</br>The loss of your favourite swain,</br>Whose presence illumin'd each vale,</br>And brighten'd the pleasantest plain.
But, why do I try to proclaim,</br>The praise of our Damon, whose worth,</br>Long ere now, on the pinions of Fame,</br>Has been borne o'er all parts of the earth.</br>
